greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Result of using the positive integers 1,2,3,... as coefficients in an infinite polynomial series in x and then expressing this series as Product_{k>=1} (1+a(k)x^k).
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..500
example: From the positive integers 1,2,3,..., construct the series 1+x+2x^2+3x^3+4x^4+... a(1) is always the coefficient of x, here 1. Divide by (1+a(1)x), i.e. here (1+x), to get the quotient (1+a(2)x^2+...), which here gives a(2)=2. Then divide this quotient by (1+a(2)x^2), i.e. here (1+2x^2), to get (1+a(3)x^3+...), giving a(3)=1.
results.author: _Neil Fernandez_, Nov 09 2008
